title: 105_hr2184
content:
The Act may be cited as the "Private Security Officer Quality Assurance Act of 1997". Congress acknowledges the rapid growth of private security officers in the United States, who play a crucial role in crime prevention and protection of various entities such as banks, hospitals, airports, and schools. Private security officers complement the services provided by sworn law enforcement officers in public areas. Private security officers play a significant role in crime prevention and protection of various entities in the United States, including complexes, schools, residential properties, and gated communities. The growth of private security services has increased contact with security personnel compared to sworn law enforcement officers. This trend has accelerated as the number of public sector law enforcement officers has decreased, serving important public policy goals. The growth of private security services has accelerated as the number of public sector law enforcement officers has decreased. The public demands well-trained private security personnel as an adjunct, not a replacement for sworn law enforcement officers. Private security officers should be screened thoroughly, especially since many carry weapons. Background checks are required for private security personnel, especially those who carry weapons. Private security officers' employers can request an association designated by the Attorney General to submit fingerprints for background checks. Employers can seek authorization from employees for fingerprint submission. The Attorney General searches crime databases and provides identification and criminal history records within 30 days. The use of advanced technology is encouraged for compiling criminal history information. The Attorney General encourages the use of advanced technology for compiling criminal history information. Associations designated under this section must submit employee fingerprints within one business day and provide identification and criminal history records to employers promptly. Associations also need to share information with licensing authorities and regulatory agencies. The Attorney General can establish necessary regulations for this process. The Attorney General may prescribe regulations for associations to provide identification and criminal history records to employers promptly. The Attorney General will report to Congress on the number of inquiries made by employers under this section after 2 years. SEC. 4. CONFORMING AMENDMENTS. Amends section 534 of title 28, US Code to include private security officer associations for conducting background checks. 

SEC. 5. CRIMINAL PENALTY. Imposes fines or imprisonment for misuse of information obtained under section 3.

SEC. 6. EMPLOYER LIABILITY. Employers relying on criminal history information provided by the Attorney General are not liable for damages in employment decisions.

SEC. 7. DEFINITIONS. Defines terms used in the preceding sections. The Act defines key terms such as "Attorney General," "employee," "employer," "fingerprint," and "private security officer." It includes individuals providing security services as independent contractors or employees. The term "private security officer" refers to individuals who provide security services for compensation, excluding sworn police officers, licensed professionals, internal auditors, military personnel, and individuals involved in reporting or apprehending shoplifters or trespassers. The term "security services" includes observation or reporting of intrusion, theft deterrence, and observation of unlawful activity. It excludes certain individuals such as internal auditors, military personnel, and employees involved in secure prisoner movement. The term "security services" encompass the observation or reporting of intrusion, theft deterrence, observation of unlawful activity, protection of individuals or property, control of access, maintenance of order and safety at public activities, and provision of canine services for detecting unlawful devices or substances. The term "State" refers to various regions including States, the District of Columbia, Puerto Rico, and other territories. SEC. 8. USER FEES.

The Attorney General can charge a user fee for obtaining an individual's criminal history information.

SEC. 9. EFFECTIVE DATE.

The Act will be effective starting July 1, 1999.
